title: Talkin Tarn Country Park Walking Route

images.title: mauldy / Footpath to Talkin Tarn
images.caption: Entrance to Talkin Tarn by Tarn End House Hotel. Lovely view across the tarn with footpath sign and gate. Taken in the summer of 2006.

images.title: Rose and Trev Clough / Bird observatory, Talkin Tarn
images.caption: The Bird observatory by the side of the tarn. The old Farlam Boathouse has recently been refurbished, and converted for birdwatching. It is one of several improvements carried out since ownership of the tarn was transferred from Cumbria County Council to Carlisle City Council in 2006.

images.title: raydar / Reds at Talkin Tarn
images.caption: A red squirrel poses for the camera on a tree in the park.

images.title: Rose and Trev Clough / Boats and ducks at Talkin Tarn
images.caption: Boats and ducks by the tarn. Local clubs for rowing, sailing and model boats are based at the Tarn. Rowing boats are available for hire at weekends and school holidays.

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Sedge Bay, Talkin Tarn
images.caption: A seat with a view at Sedge Bay, a promontory on the north east side of the tarn

images.title: Keith Fairhurst / Late Autumn at Talkin Tarn
images.caption: An autumn view in November 2006. On a woodland walk around the perimeter of the tarn, leading to Farlam.

images.title: Rose and Trev Clough / Looking across Talkin Tarn to the bird observatory
images.caption: Looking across the tarn to the bird observatory. Power to this former boathouse is provided by a small wind turbine, to its left. On the water is a great crested grebe, one of several winged visitors to the site.

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Village street, Talkin
images.caption: Stone cottages in the village of Talkin.

description: Explore this 165 acre country park in Brampton, and enjoy the large glacial tarn, mature woodland and gentle meadows with the stunning Pennine Hills as a backdrop. The park includes a well maintained path around the tarn and three other way-marked trails taking you through the surrounding woodland and fields. Facilities include a tearoom, gift shop and row boats available for hire on the tarn. Just a mile to the west you will find Gelt Woods . This is a great place to extend your walk with nice footpaths along the River Gelt and lots of wildlife to look out for in the RSPB reserve.
